ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: LEanne Pasquini and Jooyoung Park
Leanne&Jooyoung
Jooyoung Park

Leanne Pasquini and Jooyoung Park

L Pasquinni&Jooyoung Park

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The combination of problem sets, facility reports and client consultation was too much. I think the problem sets or one of the reports should be eliminated so students can focus more on the client project.

The field trips were very interesting but having them every other week for six weeks was tiresome, especially considering the effort involved in the facility visit reports.I don't think that having four faculty teach this course worked very well. It essentially made the class low on all of their priority lists. Feedback and assistance for the term project was slow in coming.

Q6,7,9,10: Some of the classes themselves were slow, but there was a good amount of work resulting from the facility visits. The visits were very useful, and mostly well organized. The initial visit (Wheelebrator) was lacking in that the environmental professional there was not available when we visited unfortunately.

Overall, the course seemed to lack a cohesive focus, although this is to be expected somewhat considering the broad range of industries, processes and disciplines being considered. Marian's lectures were incredibly informative and well-presented. Much of Tom's lectures were rehashes of the reading material. Julie's lectures were droll and uninspired. Bill Ellis' guest lecture would be better served at the end of the class to tie in the cost/benefit capacity of structuring greening financial investments.

Question 4: The course load was a bit heavier but this corresponded to a 4-credit class.Question 5: The instructors were receptive to requests by the full class to move around deadlines. Otherwise, the sheer number of instructors made delivering concepts difficult.Question 6: The course was sometimes a bit slow, particularly when the material was essentially common knowledge.Question 7: I think four professors are too many to team-teach this course. The number of instructors and the differences across their styles and perceptions of the course left the overall class feeling discombobulated and less comprehensive than expected.Question 9: Many of the field trips involved very complicated information, which we werent versed on, but were expected to understand for the related assignments. As I would like to have a thorough understanding of these business operations, it was frustrating to continue to bump into these information gaps in the basic infrastructure and engineering of the various facilities we visited.
Field trips and client project

The field trips were great, and while I didn't enjoy writing the facility reports, I actually learned a fair bit from them. I would have loved to shadow an actual sustainability consultant in a facility walk-through and get more access to concrete quantitative tools to analyze energy and water usage of facilities. More case studies and less general overview information would have been useful. In fact, I think grounding every lecture with the in-depth case study of a specific company would make the lectures significantly more useful. In lectures we reviewed what we read in the book--so I eventually stopped doing the readings. I wasn't getting much additional learning from doing both simultaneously.
The facility visits were all very interesting and gave great insights into the manufacturing sector, which few of us have had any exposure to.
I greatly enjoyed the final project. It was great to work with a real company on a project of their choosing. I also really enjoyed all of the facility visits.
Field trips&final project
Fieldtrips are provide an excellent insight into various corporate operations.
Facility visits, learning about process flows. Also working with LCA&SLCA tools was very valuable.
-The client project-Learning SimaPro and other environmental assessment metrics
Learning to use the SimaPro LCA software package.
The breadth of topics covered, which serves as a great introduction to the discipline of industrial ecology

The field trip experience was by far the best part of the course, and learning how actual industrial processes work and could improve is the essential foundation for industrial ecology. Also, if planned well and executed over time, the group project can be a real learning opportunity.
The facility visit to Curtis Packaging.
-Getting an overview of a wide variety of industries.-Field trips.-Learning to use tools like SLCA
the exposure to real world applications
The field trips were excellent in terms of learning.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: amount of work and problem sets

This course needs to address the lack of data provided by the facilities we visited and the companies we worked with for our final projects. Company representatives frequently didn't have answers to simple questions like "how much energy does this facility use in a year?" or "what are your major emissions constraints?" it would be helpful in future to have them prepare some basic facts and figures prior to the class visits. Without some of these data, the facility visit reports wound up being pretty weak.

Facility Reports- The facility reports became redundant. I think the would be more valuable if they allowed for creativity in the way the report was structured. It was unclear who the audience of the facility reports was supposed to be (Admittedly, I neglected to ask). It would likely be valuable to modify the facility report assignments so that students produce a report similar to what they might be expected to do as a consultant or other professional. Exposure to different ways of reporting on the visits would be valuable.Problem Sets- The problem sets were very simple, and so contributed little to the learning experience. The Simapro problem is an exception, but I would have liked some a "dust-off" of some sort regarding the Simapro exercise. After submitting the assignment, it would be helpful to review how someone trained in Simapro would have done the assessment.Because our exposure to SLCA was limited to the Environmentally Responsible Product Matrix, most students assumed that the ERPM is synonymous with SLCA. If SLCA is a topic of the next class, I think that discussion should include comparison of other methods besides the ERPM.
Lectures could have had more substance
Need more feedback and discussion following assignments. It seemed like we were would hand something in and then immediately move on to the next topic

Professor Zimmerman's slides were very cluttered and resulted in a lot of reading verbatim from the instructor. This is something that most of us have been instructed to avoid in our own presentations, including in this class. So the opportunity exists to teach by example in this case.

-It would be great to have real experts talk about supply chains, EMS who know this stuff. Pulling some text from a website of a corporation engaged in CSR is not the same as what is really going on in the field.-Zimmerman talks too fast-There were way to many field trip reports that it became very redundant and didn't encourage further learning-There were inconsistencies between the syllabus and actual grading; the TAs graded the assignments differently, sometimes too harshly-Bad communication between students, TAs, and professors-Course lectures didn't cover the readings at all and were extremely general
Somewhat beyond the control of the instructors - facility personnel giving tours of the grounds could have provided more pertinent information that was more relevant to our report writing.
The lectures somehow needed to engage more with the excitement of the projects and trips. I think more case studies might be a part of this.
Better direction and more through guidance on the group term projects

More use of environmental accounting. Weight problem sets more evenly with the effort required. Make students participate more, don't let us get away with being lazy and not discussing things or not answering questions.
the slow pace of in-class learning and the lack of direct connection between what happens out of the classroom with what happens in the classroom

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Good TA support, and quick turn-around responses to emails.
Our professor adviser for our group project had limited availability but the TAs were incredible. They were always on top of class business and great sources of insight.
The instructors didnot hold office hours. Instructors met with each group regarding final projects.
Excellent
I found it somewhat challenging to get in touch with the professors outside of class hours. TA's were very responsive to questions.
Instructors weren't very communicative about logistics
Marian/Tom/Jooyoung - n/aLeanne - above and beyond phenomenalJulie - poor/unhelpful
High quality advice was always readily available

The instructors and TAs were generally pretty helpful. However, we were unaware of our faculty "contacts" for the group project until more than a month after the project started; that was unacceptable.

Leanne was great. Marian was receptive but not very helpful, which was also the case when I sought out Tom Graedel for help. I set up a meeting with Julie Zimmerman, which she failed to show up for. I was unable to get her to reschedule this meeting, despite following up by email.
Often went to Leeanne's office hours, she was a great help. Both Leeanne and Jooyoung were very responsive to emails. Professors, particularly Matt Eckelman, were also very available for questions.
I was in contact with TAs and they were very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I did really enjoy the class, but there were large parts of the lectures and field trips focused on industrial facilities and industries that did not interest me at all.
I am loosely interested in means of evaluating environmental services so the corporate trend toward sustainability interests me indirectly.

This course fits in with the Industrial Ecology focus, and is considered a foundation for the topic. It does a good job of introducing you to different kinds of industrial sectors and providing some fundamentals of industrial ecology and green design.
Core course in the area of Industrial Ecology/ Business Environmental Practices which is my focus area.
For anyone into Industrial Ecology or unfamiliar with how the manufacturing industry approaches environmental issues this is an essential foundational course.
It adds to the breadth of my professional training in Environmental Management
Since I am interested in the business and environment relationship, this course was a fairly good introduction to the issues in this nexus.

I wish we'd looked more thoroughly into understanding the actual systems in place at each facility we visited. I'm very interested in the engineering basis but this class failed to cover such in-depth material, while still expecting us to understand the conceptual framework.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in industrial ecology and understanding more about the private sector&industry operate, and opportunities for environmental improvements in their operations.
To learn SimaPro and an interest in greening business operations
For the same reason I gave in question 15
To get a good grounding of environmental business issues and lay the context for future industrial ecology study.
I'd heard good things.
To learn how to "green business operations" and to learn about a variety of businesses in general.
Besides, to fulfill my Bin requirement, i took this course to understand the life cycle analysis of materials to ensure sustainability of the product.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: I actually still feel like a novice in this field. I think a course that aimed to be less an overview of everything and go deeper into certain tools would be ideal. I think preparing students, at least for the first facility visit, with a long list of examples of the types of questions a sustainability expert would ask to generate a report, would have been helpful.
Yes, but just too much work to do.
Not really. I expected to gain quantitative skills for assessing corporate environmental performance. In the end it seemed like everything we did was rooted in questionable assumptions.
As a whole, I really enjoyed the course. There are a few things that could be refined to make the class more valuable, but overall it did live up to my expectations.
Yes
Yes
To some extent - though the lectures were so general/broad that I felt like I already knew what they discussed in class and I zoned out a bit.

Although I feel as though I gained much from the course, somehow the finish felt anticlimactic. That being said, I am cognizant that, if the subject matter were reordered, I would say that the course did indeed live up to my expectations.
Yes
Absolutely.

The field trips definitely did. However, the lectures and problem sets were less engaging and helpful, and I think that the group project was cumbersome, with slow moving corporate communication and unclear objectives.

No, I was disappointed in the lack of guidance I received with the group term project, despite reaching out to two of the instructors and the client. It made the project feel unfulfilling and disappointing.
Above and beyond.
It was excellent.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Not really. Although it did give me a better introduction to industrial ecology, which I will probably take more of in the future.
Yes

Yes - though I hope to learn more about&use LCA, SLCA, and Input-Output tools in other classes, hopefully Industrial Ecology. If that's the case, then this course was a good introduction. If not, then we should use them even more in this class.
Yes
Yes, and a lot more. The expanse of topics covered was much more than what I'd expected.
Again, I think I would have gotten much more out of this course with proper guidance on the term project and better explanations of the full facility systems.
More.
Yes. The practical's and field work was excellent in helping me understand the concepts and processes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: advantages: good exercise, better productdisadvantages: group dynamics were challenging and time consuming

I actually learned at least as much working solo on the facility reports, as I had to do more internet research and rely more on my notes and memory.But I did enjoy the group work on our term projects. It's challenging when every group member has different priorities and a different level of commitment to the project, but all in all, we worked well together.

the group assigned to our project was very cumbersome. There were eight people working on largely separate tasks and coordination was a challenge. It felt like we spent more time meeting and trying to establish plans for work than actually working.

Advantages: Problem solving in real life typically involves group work, so this was good practice. Helps expose you to the different knowledge bases and skill sets of peers. Creates accountability to do quality work.Disadvantages: Not everyone is willing to do same amount of work. Sometimes have to compromise the way you think something should be done (this is both good and bad).
Good to divide up the workload, hard to coordinate a times.

Group project was an excellent opportunity to get a little more in-depth with a particular topic. Would have been nice to have a little more guidance/ feedback from the professors on the group project.

Nearly all the work was group work, which had numerous advantages. Many real-world projects are performed by teams; and in this field there are a great number of components to track, so its good to have more than one set of eyes, ears,&brains collaborating on the problems/solutions.
It was good to work in groups and share the workload of the client projects
Allowed us to really engage with the GBO tools and methods in an applied capacity.
The group work held the promise of being a great, interactive project for a real company, but the very short timeline and limited information left us wanting more out of it.
Group work was difficult due to the insufficient guidance we received. I appreciated hearing my peers' perspectives.
the advantage was varying perspectives, the disadvantage was varying levels of understanding of the project and levels of caring about project outcome
Working in groups was excellent way to share ideas and knowledge.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: My foremost criticism about the class was the overall lack of data. A consistent theme was finding ways of improving business processes from an environmental impact standpoint. However, at many of the facilities we visited the management was not forthcoming with the information necessary to establish what their baseline environmental performance was. Our group project was to conduct a life cycle assessment for a major manufacturer, whose representatives didn't give us the data necessary to even understand some of the more obscure processes. Inevitably we had to make assumptions in order to circumvent these problems, which I knew would happen occasionally when the curriculum was outlined, but it happened so frequently that I didn't feel like we got any experience producing justifiable environmental analyses of business processes.

Ask the instructors ahead of time what kind of questions to ask at the facility visits. After the first one or two, you start to learn this on your own, but it will be helpful for your first report(s) if you already have the mindset of an environmental professional. Also, participate in the give&take of the everyday class with comments/questions, or you may feel bored.
Choose a client project that excites you. Try to be innovative in applying what is learned in the class to the project.
Choose a topic that you really enjoy for the group assignment and choose your team mates well (if possible)

Try to get as much detail out of the field trips as possible, because getting more of a sense (in order of magnitude estimates) of where the biggest environmental impacts are would be helpful, because all too often this class can get into vagaries.
Carefully evaluate whether the facility visited scheduled are to places/industries of interest to you, rather than just whether the course as a whole looks relevant to your career aspirations.

Write out a skeleton of your facility report before going on the visit. The headings and sections can all be written beforehand by looking at the book's examples, also, most of the introduction information for the facility can be found online before going to the site.
class attendance and reading is, unfortunately, optional

This is an important if you are interested in environmental management and industrial ecology. The Prof. are excellent and the field trips are very educative. However, this has a heavy course work including five field trips and a project work.
